# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Data

df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
audi_filter(df_cars)

Here is the function `audi_filter` which follows your instructions:

```julia
using DataFrames

function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    # Filter down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”
    df_filtered = filter(row -> row[:manufacturer] == "audi" && (row[:model] == "a4" || row[:model] == "a4 quattro"), df)
    
    # Create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows in the filtered DataFrame
    insertcols!(df_filtered, :audi_a4_type => true)

    return df_filtered
end
```

Now we can use this function on the provided data:

```julia
df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])

new_df = audi_filter(df_cars)
```

The `new_df` DataFrame will now only include rows where the manufacturer is Audi and the model is either an a4 or an a4 quattro. Additionally, every row in this new DataFrame will have an `audi_a4_type` column with value `true`.
